message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of fever, flank pain, hematuria, and rash is consistent with acute interstitial nephritis. The presence of numerous eosinophils on urinalysis also supports this diagnosis. Interstitial T-cell infiltration is a characteristic finding on histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen in cases of acute interstitial nephritis. Mesangial IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis is seen in renal papillary necrosis, and cortical cyst formation is seen in acquired cystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the rash and eosinophils in the urine, suggest that the patient has drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis. The most likely histologic finding would be interstitial T-cell infiltration. Mesangial IgA deposition is associated with IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis is associated with pyelonephritis and nephrolithiasis, and cortical cyst formation is associated with polycystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute interstitial nephritis, which is commonly caused by medications like meloxicam. Interstitial T-cell infiltration is the hallmark histologic finding in acute interstitial nephritis, while the other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute interstitial nephritis, which is commonly caused by drug reactions. The patient’s chronic back pain medication, meloxicam, is a common offender. The histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen would most likely show interstitial T-cell infiltration. Mesangial IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy. Papillary necrosis is seen in pyelonephritis or analgesic nephropathy. Cortical cyst formation is seen in polycystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with fever, flank pain, and hematuria, which are suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), a type of kidney inflammation. The diffuse maculopapular rash and eosinophils in the urine suggest a drug-induced AIN. Meloxicam, which the patient has been taking, is a known cause of AIN. Interstitial T-cell infiltration is the most likely histologic finding in AIN. The other options are unrelated to AIN.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest drug-induced interstitial nephritis, which is characterized by a diffuse interstitial infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) interstitial T-cell infiltration. The other options are not associated with drug-induced interstitial nephritis. Mesangial IgA deposition is a feature of IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis is associated with analgesic nephropathy, and cortical cyst formation is a feature of polycystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute interstitial nephritis, which is commonly caused by medications like meloxicam. The presence of eosinophils in the urine also supports this diagnosis. Interstitial T-cell infiltration is a hallmark histologic finding in acute interstitial nephritis. The other options are less likely to be seen on biopsy in this clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab findings suggest acute interstitial nephritis, which is commonly caused by drug reactions. The rash also supports this diagnosis. Treatment involves stopping the offending agent and sometimes using corticosteroids. Interstitial T-cell infiltration is a characteristic finding in the histologic examination of kidney biopsy specimens with acute interstitial nephritis. Mesangial IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis occurs in analgesic nephropathy, and cortical cyst formation is seen in polycystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab findings suggest acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), which is commonly associated with drug-induced hypersensitivity reactions. AIN is characterized by interstitial inflammation and lymphocytic infiltration, making option (B) the only correct answer. Mesangial IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis is seen in analgesic nephropathy, and cortical cyst formation is seen in polycystic kidney disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and urinalysis results suggest acute interstitial nephritis, which is often associated with drug-induced allergic reactions. The maculopapular rash further supports this diagnosis. The most likely histologic finding in this case would be interstitial T-cell infiltration. Mesangial IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, papillary necrosis can be seen in pyelonephritis, and cortical cyst formation is a feature of polycystic kidney disease.
